text: EXCLUSIVE: An event contractor for Town & Country magazine is revealing her experience with racism at the 174-year-old Hearst publication in a gut-wrenching essay for The Daily Beast https://t.co/YXzeSEaFx7

name: thedailybeast
text: After seeing several statements in the wake of the George Floyd killing about their commitment to racial justice, Verneda White just couldn’t take it anymore. In her eyes, the magazine was putting up a big front https://t.co/xA7LxJKxvD

name: thedailybeast
text: White’s industry peers warned her that speaking out could be damaging to her career but she is committed to bringing these inequalities to light https://t.co/xA7LxJKxvD

name: thedailybeast
text:
“My only choice was to press on with the fortitude of the Black suffragettes, the inspiration of Kamala Harris’ unprecedented run, and John Lewis’ iconic final words held tightly to my chest,” White writes 
https://t.co/xA7LxJKxvD

name: thedailybeast
text: What she says she saw every day included an endless parade of blond white women hired to replace the one just before—with little consideration for anyone else—and only one Black low-level editorial staffer during her tenure https://t.co/xA7LxJKxvD

name: thedailybeast
text: Town & Country regularly billed A-list Black talent—the likes of John Legend and Michael B. Jordan—to headline their annual summit, an event White’s company coordinated, while lacking any representation on staff https://t.co/xA7LxJKxvD

name: thedailybeast
text: White says she was denied opportunities for advancement and was pushed to the side when it came to executing this year’s summit, which was virtual due to the pandemic https://t.co/xA7LxJKxvD

name: thedailybeast
text: She sat in for the 4-day summit and listened to Ava DuVernay. That’s when White says she decided to reach out to the EIC and requested an opportunity to address her concerns in an article https://t.co/xA7LxJKxvD

name: thedailybeast
text: After one follow-up meeting, the article was effectively canned. White says she was given more empty messaging from HR about their commitment to equity https://t.co/xA7LxJKxvD

name: thedailybeast
text: Read more of this exclusive piece, which includes an account of another Black staffer who finally decided to leave Town & Country after years of being passed over for promotions: https://t.co/xA7LxJKxvD

name: thedailybeast
text: Bo Dietl, Bernie Kerik, Keith Ablow and the authors of “Lucifer’s Banker” are all jumping into the saga that Trump hopes will win him a second term. https://t.co/W0mG1Uwm2k

name: thedailybeast
text:
EXCLUSIVE: A former events contractor for Town & Country magazine reveals her experience with systemic racism at the 174-year-old Hearst publication in a gut-wrenching essay for The Daily Beast
https://t.co/r8T8dn4Th2

name: thedailybeast
text:
After seeing several statements in the wake of the George Floyd killing about Town & Country’s commitment to racial justice, Verneda Adele White just couldn’t take it anymore. 

In her eyes, the magazine was putting up a big front.

https://t.co/vpHdodMPil

name: thedailybeast
text:
White’s industry peers warned her that speaking out could be damaging to her career but she is committed to bringing these inequalities to light

https://t.co/vpHdodMPil

name: thedailybeast
text: “My only choice was to press on with the fortitude of the Black suffragettes, the inspiration of Kamala Harris’ unprecedented run, and John Lewis’ iconic final words held tightly to my chest.” https://t.co/vpHdodMPil

name: thedailybeast
text: White writes that over the four years she worked there, she was denied opportunities for advancement, experienced pay inequity, and witnessed the only Black full-time magazine staffer resign in frustration after years of being treated differently https://t.co/vpHdodMPil

name: thedailybeast
text:
Town & Country regularly billed A-list Black talent—to headline their annual summit. 

But “behind the scenes,” White writes, “a very different story emerges—one that has all the hallmarks of deep-seated systemic racism and bias.” https://t.co/vpHdodMPil

name: thedailybeast
text:
She sat in for the 4-day summit and listened to Ava DuVernay. 

That’s when White says she decided to reach out to the EIC and requested an opportunity to address her concerns in a Town & Country article about racial reconciliation. https://t.co/vpHdodMPil

name: thedailybeast
text:
After one follow-up meeting, the article was effectively canned. 

White says she was given more empty messaging from the magazine about their commitment to racial equity. 
https://t.co/vpHdodMPil

name: thedailybeast
text: Read more of this exclusive piece, which includes an account of a Black full-time staffer who finally decided to leave Town & Country after years of being passed over for promotions:  https://t.co/vpHdodMPil

name: thedailybeast
text:
⚡️ “I Experienced Systemic Racism at This Prestigious Magazine”

https://t.co/wKGVvNCzn4
